newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn ends higher on late fund buying, exports.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn ends higher on late fund buying, exports.

text.p: CBOT corn futures closed mostly higher on a late fund buying rally with strong weekly USDA export inspections lending support, traders said.
USDA Monday said 38.9 million bushels of corn were inspected in the week ended January 23. That figure, on top of last week's 42.4 million, was considered supportive.
Slow farmer selling contributed to gains. Cash bids firmed in some areas as farmers remained reluctant to sell.
Corn had traded weaker most of the day in response to Friday's surprisingly low USDA cattle on feed placement data, traders said.
USDA said the number of cattle placed on feed in the primary U.S. states during December totaled 1.423 million head, down two percent from a year ago and 10 percent below analysts' expectations.
But heavy fund buying late reversed the trend. Griffin Trading, Refco Inc and FIMAT Futures were among the late buyers, traders said.
On the day, Smith Barney bought at least seven to nine million bushels of corn. Tenco Inc bought one million March and 1.2 million July, traders said.
Corn closed 2-1/4 cents per bushel higher to 1/4 cent lower with March up 2-1/4 at $2.75.
Technical traders said another close above $2.75 in the March could attract some fund buying. Support was pegged at $2.72-3/4 per bushel and resistance at $2.76-1/2, they said.
Corn volume was estimated at 40,000 contracts, CBOT said. That compared with Friday's actual volume of 39,652 contracts.
